Authors:
Jiranan Techaprasan, Saroj Ruchisansakun, Timo van der
Niet, Steven B Janssens, Pramote Triboun, Thaya Jenjittikul, Piyakaset
Suksathan
Title:
Phylogenetic analyses of molecular data suggest redefinition
of the Southeast Asian subgenus Semeiocardium (Impatiens:
Balsaminaceae).
Keywords:
atpB-rbcL intergenic spacer, ITS, Morphology, Southeast
Asia, synapomorphy, taxonomy
Abstract:
Phylogenetic analysis has revealed extensive evolutionary
lability of morphological characters in the large genus Impatiens, which
has complicated subgeneric systematics. However, taxa from Southeast
Asia were under-represented in previous phylogenetic studies and their
systematic status remains unclear. In this study we evaluate the
systematic status of the Southeast Asian subgenus Semeiocardium. Using a
phylogenetic analysis of 164 accessions, including 15 members of
Semeiocardium as well as many newly added taxa from Southeast Asia, we
test the monophyly of Semeiocardium and reconstruct the evolution of
several key morphological characters that have been used in taxanomic
treatments of Semeiocardium. Both Bayesian and Parsimony analyses of DNA
sequences from the nuclear ITS and plastid atpB-rbcL intergenic spacer
respectively, demonstrated that Semeiocardium is not monophyletic.
Thirteen representatives are part of a large clade, which also includes
many other Southeast Asian taxa. Connate lateral united petals are a
synapomorphy of this clade, while a 4-locular ovary and connate outer
lateral sepals are not. Impatiens muscicola and I. santisukii, which
were previously classified under subgenus Semeiocardium, do not belong
to the clade with connate lateral united petals. Re-examination of
floral morphological characters of these two species revealed that their
character states were previously misinterpreted; their lateral united
petals and outer lateral sepals are free, and their ovary is 5-locular.
Based on these results we propose a redefined subgenus Semeiocardium,
which includes all species with connate lateral united petals. We
conclude that reconstructing the evolution of morphological characters
in a phylogenetic context can facilitate identification of key
diagnostic traits for accurate subgeneric taxonomy in Impatiens.
